name: Pre-Purchase Electrical Inspection
description: Before you buy that house, know exactly what you're getting into electrically. Solomon Electric provides pre-purchase electrical inspections that go far beyond what general home inspectors check—examining panels, wiring, outlets, and safety systems to reveal hidden problems. Our detailed reports help you negotiate repairs or make informed buying decisions.
warningSignsHeading: Why Home Buyers Need Electrical Inspection
warningSignsSubheading: General home inspections barely scratch the surface of electrical issues. Here's what you need to know.

problems.title: General Inspector Limitations
problems.description: Home inspectors check basic function but aren't electricians. They miss panel issues, wiring problems, and code violations that licensed electricians catch.

problems.title: Hidden Wiring Problems
problems.description: Aluminum wiring, knob-and-tube, undersized circuits, and unpermitted work hide behind walls. These can cost thousands to address.

problems.title: Panel Recalls and Hazards
problems.description: Certain panel brands (Federal Pacific, Zinsco, Pushmatic) have known safety issues. A licensed electrician identifies dangerous equipment.

problems.title: Inadequate Service
problems.description: Older homes with 100-amp or smaller service may need expensive upgrades for modern usage, EV chargers, or additions.

problems.title: DIY and Unpermitted Work
problems.description: Previous owners often do electrical work incorrectly. Inspection reveals improper installations hiding behind finishes.

problems.title: Negotiation Leverage
problems.description: Documented electrical issues provide negotiation power—seller repairs, price reductions, or credits for future work.

process.title: Panel Examination
process.description: We thoroughly examine the electrical panel for capacity, condition, recalled brands, connection quality, and any signs of problems.

process.title: Wiring Assessment
process.description: We identify wiring type (copper, aluminum, knob-and-tube) and assess visible wiring condition in accessible areas.

process.title: Outlet and Safety Testing
process.description: We test outlets for proper grounding and polarity, verify GFCI function in required locations, and check for missing safety protection.

process.title: Code Compliance Review
process.description: We identify obvious code violations that would require correction—especially important for homes with previous unpermitted work.

process.title: Report and Recommendations
process.description: You receive a detailed written report with findings, safety concerns, repair recommendations, and cost estimates for negotiation support.

benefits.title: Avoid Expensive Surprises
benefits.description: Discovering major electrical repairs after closing is devastating. Pre-purchase inspection reveals these hidden expenses before you commit to the purchase.

benefits.title: Negotiation Power
benefits.description: Documented electrical issues support requesting seller repairs, price reductions, or closing credits for future work.

benefits.title: Safety Awareness
benefits.description: Know about any hazardous conditions—Federal Pacific panels, aluminum wiring, missing GFCI—before your family moves in.

benefits.title: Budget Planning
benefits.description: Even if you proceed with the purchase, knowing electrical condition helps budget for needed upgrades.

faqs.question: Why isn't the general home inspection enough?
faqs.answer: General home inspectors aren't licensed electricians. They typically spend 10 minutes on electrical—checking that lights work and the panel isn't obviously damaged. They don't identify recalled panels, wiring problems, code violations, or capacity issues. Electrical problems are the #1 thing home inspectors miss.

faqs.question: When should I schedule the electrical inspection?
faqs.answer: Schedule during your inspection period—the same timeframe as your general home inspection. Coordinate timing so you can negotiate or walk away based on findings. Don't wait until after your inspection period expires.

faqs.question: What if you find serious problems?
faqs.answer: Serious findings give you options: request seller repairs before closing, negotiate price reduction to cover repair costs, request seller credit at closing, or walk away if issues are too severe. Your realtor can help you negotiate using our documented findings.

faqs.question: How much do typical repairs cost?
faqs.answer: Costs vary depending on the scope of the project. Minor functional repairs are typically modest, while major items like panel replacements or whole-house remediation are more significant investments. We provide detailed estimates in our report to give you clear guidance for your negotiations.

faqs.question: What if the house has aluminum wiring?
faqs.answer: Aluminum branch circuit wiring (common 1965-1975) presents fire risks at connections. It doesn't require immediate replacement but needs proper connectors and monitoring. We identify aluminum wiring and explain the implications for your buying decision.

faqs.question: Is the inspection worth it for newer homes?
faqs.answer: Even newer homes benefit from inspection. We find issues in homes 5-10 years old—improper DIY work, builder shortcuts, and early failures. The cost of inspection is insignificant compared to unexpected repairs.

faqs.question: Do you provide repair estimates for negotiation?
faqs.answer: Yes. Our reports include estimated repair costs for identified issues. This documentation supports your negotiation position with solid numbers rather than guesses.

faqs.question: Can you do the repairs if I buy the house?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. If you purchase and want us to handle recommended repairs, we already understand the property and can prioritize work appropriately. Many clients return to us after closing for repairs identified during inspection.

seoContent.heading: Pre-Purchase Electrical Inspection in South Florida
seoContent.body: Before you buy that South Florida home, know exactly what you're getting into electrically. Solomon Electric provides pre-purchase electrical inspections that go beyond home inspector basics—revealing hidden problems that could cost thousands to repair. Our detailed reports support your buying decision and negotiation.

seoContent.heading: What Home Inspectors Miss
seoContent.body: General home inspectors check that lights work and the panel isn't on fire—that's about it. They miss panel recalls (Federal Pacific, Zinsco), aluminum wiring hazards, undersized service, code violations, and evidence of improper DIY work. A licensed electrician catches what they miss.

seoContent.heading: Negotiate with Documentation
seoContent.body: Our inspection reports provide the documentation you need for negotiation. Identified issues, safety concerns, and repair cost estimates give you leverage to request seller repairs, price reductions, or closing credits. Don't inherit problems—know before you buy.

seoContent.heading: Protecting South Florida Home Buyers
seoContent.body: Solomon Electric provides pre-purchase electrical inspections throughout Miami, Fort Lauderdale, Hollywood, Coral Gables, Pembroke Pines, and all surrounding communities. Protect your investment with thorough electrical inspection before you commit.
